clinical_study.brief_title: Optical Sensor for Photodynamic Detection of Oral Pathology
clinical_study.official_title: Optical Sensor for Photodynamic Detection of Oral Pathology

collaborator.agency: Beckman Laser Institute University of California Irvine

brief_summary.textblock: Overall objective of this work is to identify changes in the optical properties of tissues, and to compare these with conventional semi-quantitative histo-pathological assessment to (1) gain a better understanding of processes involved in oral pathology and (2) develop a non-invasive tool for the detection, diagnosis and screening of oral pathology.

detailed_description.textblock:
The researcher can use Optical Sensor for imaging the oral tissues. The Imaging system is a non-invasive imaging device and can measure the change in oral tissues. This imaging device is a non-invasive, non-significant risk use for optical tissue biopsy and can reduce procedural complication from clinical standard surgical tissue biopsy procedure.
The imaging devices are;
1. Coherence and Doppler Tomography (OCT)
2. Laser Speckle Imaging (LSI)
3. Photon Migration Spectroscopy (PMS)
The researcher use toothpaste call Livionex Colgate Product to evaluate oral tissues changes and use the imaging devices to measure the changes of oral tissues.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.description: Develop a non-invasive tool for the detection, diagnosis and screening of oral pathology and understanding of processes involved in oral pathology

study_pop.textblock: Study population will be recruited from University of Californis Irvine and Orange Country Dentists.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or Female age 18 years and older
- Have oral lesion or not have oral lesion
- Have condition of dry mouth
- Have condition of Gum disease
- Non-smoker
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age less than 18 years old
- Advanced gum disease, diseases of oral tissue
- Untreated cavities
- Pregnant or breastfeeding
- Immune compromised individuals
